title: Mount Wanous
text:
Mount Wanous is a prominent, bare, conical <a href="mountain">mountain</a>, 1,660 m, standing 4.5 nautical miles (8 km) east of <a href="Pierce%20Peak%20%28Antarctica%29">Pierce Peak</a> at the northeast edge of <a href="Mackin%20Table">Mackin Table</a> in the <a href="Patuxent%20Range">Patuxent Range</a>, <a href="Pensacola%20Mountains">Pensacola Mountains</a>, <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.
It was mapped by the <a href="United%20States%20Geological%20Survey">United States Geological Survey</a> (USGS) from surveys and <a href="U.S.%20Navy">U.S. Navy</a> air photos from 1956 to 1966. It was named by the <a href="Advisory%20Committee%20on%20Antarctic%20Names">Advisory Committee on Antarctic Names</a> (US-ACAN) for <a href="Richard%20E.%20Wanous">Richard E. Wanous</a>, a geophysicist in the Pensacola Mountains between 1965 and 1966.
